note.title: If BY RUDYARD KIPLING
note: If you can keep your head when all about you {%BR_TAB%}Are losing theirs and blaming it on you, {%BR%}If you can trust yourself when all men doubt you, {%BR_TAB%}But make allowance for their doubting too; {%BR%}If you can wait and not be tired by waiting, {%BR_TAB%}Or being lied about, don’t deal in lies, {%BR%}Or being hated, don’t give way to hating, {%BR_TAB%}And yet don’t look too good, nor talk too wise:

If you can dream—and not make dreams your master; {%BR_TAB%}If you can think—and not make thoughts your aim; {%BR%}If you can meet with Triumph and Disaster {%BR_TAB%}And treat those two impostors just the same; {%BR%}If you can bear to hear the truth you’ve spoken {%BR_TAB%}Twisted by knaves to make a trap for fools, {%BR%}Or watch the things you gave your life to, broken, {%BR_TAB%}And stoop and build ’em up with worn-out tools:

If you can make one heap of all your winnings {%BR_TAB%}And risk it on one turn of pitch-and-toss, {%BR%}And lose, and start again at your beginnings {%BR_TAB%}And never breathe a word about your loss; {%BR%}If you can force your heart and nerve and sinew {%BR_TAB%}To serve your turn long after they are gone, {%BR%}And so hold on when there is nothing in you {%BR_TAB%}Except the Will which says to them: ‘Hold on!’

If you can talk with crowds and keep your virtue, {%BR_TAB%}Or walk with Kings—nor lose the common touch, {%BR%}If neither foes nor loving friends can hurt you, {%BR_TAB%}If all men count with you, but none too much; {%BR%}If you can fill the unforgiving minute {%BR_TAB%}With sixty seconds’ worth of distance run, {%BR%}Yours is the Earth and everything that’s in it, {%BR_TAB%}And—which is more—you’ll be a Man, my son!
